title: South American population history revisited: multidisciplinary perspectives on the Upper Amazon
descriptions:
The proposed project, titled "South American population history revisited: multidisciplinary perspectives on the Upper Amazon," aims to investigate the evolution of linguistic diversity in the Upper Amazon region of western South America. By employing a multi-disciplinary approach that combines geographical, socio-historical, and communicative perspectives, this project seeks to uncover past events such as migrations, language shifts, exogamy, and trade. Through this investigation, the project hopes to understand the complex interaction between ecology, human behavior, and cognition in shaping linguistic diversity.

The significance of understanding linguistic diversity lies in its ability to reveal past events like migration and historical contact between societies, providing valuable insights into the social dynamics that have shaped human history. The project will focus on two key diversity patterns in the Upper Amazon region: the extremely diverse north and south regions with signs of local language contact, and the central region dominated by three language families indicating different stages of expansion.

By reconstructing the geographical, socio-historical, and communicative layers of history, the project aims to contribute to a deeper understanding of the social dynamics that have shaped linguistic diversity in the region. Ultimately, this research has the potential to shed light on the broader implications of using linguistic diversity as a window into our shared past.
